samples.question: And why is math so important?
samples.transcript: I think it is very fundamental for a lot of degrees and a lot of not just educational but occupational things that you might go into. Math has always provided to be a basis for everything.
samples.transcript_original: I think it is very fundamental for a lot of degrees and a lot of not just educational but occupational things that you might go into. Math has always provided to be a basis for everything.

samples.question: And is maths easy for everyone?
samples.transcript: No, I cannot say that it is. I think it is a personality trait that you are either more inclined Towards mathematical thinking or you are not. In this section she talked about math. Or you can say maths. You know that math is the American way to say maths or mathematics. You can say either. does not really matter. But in this section Saskia used some great language. She says you are more inclined. She talked about personality. Some people are more inclined. Other people are not inclined. And that means that they have some tendency or trait that they have an ability to do something.

samples.question: What makes you smile?
samples.transcript: Everything, as you can tell. Everything will make me smile. I think I am a very smiley person.

samples.question: When they are happy, when they are loving in love, just excited.

samples.question: Do you smile when you are having a photo?
samples.transcript: I try to. I try to. But you know, sometimes you have got to give that, that steely, the blue steel look I think it is called. that is the one. A pose. A pose. I am going to give you a topic and I would like you to talk about it for one to two minutes. The only piece of feedback that I would give to Saskia here is that at times some of her answers are a little bit short and I feel that she could elaborate a little bit more on her answers. For example, she talked about whether people smile in photographs. And she could say, well yeah, I tend to smile often in photographs, but I suppose it depends on the situation. If it is an active photograph and we are, doing something, then maybe there is no chance to smile. But she did, use a word which I am not that familiar with, but I am not doubting her. It was a blue steel smile. I do not really use that phrase very often, but I think it is probably true. You can talk about having a steely complexion, which means that you are quite stern and you do not always smile. So somebody who has a steely complexion might not smile so often.

samples.question: And I spoke to Saskia after her test and I said, why did you use the word advertisement?
samples.transcript: Advertisement. And she said, yeah, I know. Actually, in my country, in Sri Lanka, we say advertisement.
samples.transcript_original: Advertisement. And she said, yeah, I know. Actually, in my country, in Sri Lanka, we say advertisement.
samples.transcript_cleaned: Advertisement. And she said, yeah, I know. Actually, in my country, in Sri Lanka, we say advertisement.

samples.question: Why do companies advertise?
samples.transcript: Because it attracts the attention of consumers and they can capitalize on their product.
samples.transcript_original: Because it attracts the attention of consumers and they can capitalize on their product.
samples.transcript_cleaned: Because it attracts the attention of consumers and they can capitalize on their product.

samples.question: Do you know what a product placement is?
samples.transcript: Well, it is when you see something on a TV show or, on TV, which is advertising a product, but you do not actually, realise it is an advertisement. it is sitting, maybe there is a, a cup sitting on the desk, or maybe there is a car in the background. that is called product placement. She also said, it is commonplace. She said, it is so commonplace.

samples.question: Should advertising be regulated?
samples.transcript: I think it should be because otherwise we fall into, we are in a very capitalist economy and society and I think that without the regulation of advertisements you do not actually realize that you are being advertised to and you lose that sense of control over yourself, your spending, you do not have any autonomy.
samples.transcript_original: I think it should be because otherwise we fall into, we're in a very capitalist economy and society and I think that without the regulation of advertisements you don't actually realize that you are being advertised to and you lose that sense of control over yourself, your spending, you don't have any autonomy.
samples.transcript_cleaned: I think it should be because otherwise we fall into, we are in a very capitalist economy and society and I think that without the regulation of advertisements you do not actually realize that you are being advertised to and you lose that sense of control over yourself, your spending, you do not have any autonomy.

samples.question: Did you catch Saskia saying the word advertisement again?
samples.transcript: Yep, it crept in and I think the examiner would notice that. Such a shame. Great speech by the way. She is talking at length using great, great language.
samples.transcript_original: Yep, it crept in and I think the examiner would notice that. Such a shame. Great speech by the way. She's talking at length using great, great language.

samples.question: Is celebrity endorsement a good or a bad thing?
samples.transcript: I understand how for the companies it could be a good thing. it is an excellent way to get, you know, the layman's attention. But at the same time, like you said, I do believe that it has to be regulated. Because celebrity endorsement is excellent. And it is very, very effective. But at the same time, it does come with its, you know, issues.
samples.transcript_original: I understand how for the companies it could be a good thing. It's an excellent way to get, you know, the layman's attention. But at the same time, it does come with its, you know, issues.

samples.question: Have you ever found yourself buying something because a celebrity promoted it?
